title: Open Image
description: Open the image in Photoshop to begin the editing process.
original_steps: Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop.
Open the image in Photoshop.
Open Photoshop and load the image you want to edit.
Open the image in Photoshop.

title: Select Object
description: Select the object to be removed using a selection tool.
original_steps: Select the object you want to remove using the Quick Selection Tool or Lasso Tool.
Use the Pen tool (shortcut P) to create a precise selection around the object you want to remove.
Use the Polygonal Lasso Tool to make a selection around the object.
Select the Lasso Tool by pressing 'L' on your keyboard.
Use the Lasso Tool to draw a selection around the object you want to remove.
Select the object to remove using one of the selection tools: Quick Selection Tool, Lasso Tool, Polygonal Lasso Tool, Quick Mask Mode, or Pen Tool.
Select the Lasso tool by pressing 'L' on your keyboard or finding it in the toolbar.
Create a selection around the object you want to remove, leaving some space around it.

title: Refine Selection
description: Ensure the selection is precise and has some space around the object.
original_steps: Save the path for future use by going to the Paths tab and renaming the work path.
Convert the path to a selection by holding Ctrl (or Command) and clicking on the path thumbnail.
Feather the selection by going to Select > Modify > Feather and applying a 1-2 pixel feather.
If needed, expand the selection by going to Select > Modify > Expand to ensure there's space around the object.
Set the feather to 10 pixels and ensure Anti-Aliased is checked in the Options bar.

title: Duplicate Layer
description: Duplicate the layer to keep a clean copy of the original image for nondestructive editing.
original_steps: Duplicate the layer to keep a clean copy of the original image.

title: Remove Object
description: Use a removal method to eliminate the object from the image.
original_steps: Use Content-Aware Fill to remove the selected object: - Press Shift + Delete (Shift + Backspace on Windows) to open the Fill dialog box. - Choose Content-Aware and click OK.
For moving objects, use the Content-Aware Move Tool: - Select the object with the Lasso Tool. - Drag the object to a new position and press Enter to apply.
Create a new layer and use the Clone Stamp tool to sample an area and paint over the object within the selection.
Go to Edit > Content-Aware Fill and apply the default settings.
Go to the 'Edit' menu and select 'Content-Aware Fill'.
Use Content-Aware Fill to remove the object: Press Ctrl + Backspace, set contents to Content-Aware Fill, and click OK.
Click on 'Generative Fill' in the Contextual taskbar and then click 'Generate' without adding a prompt.

title: Adjust Removal
description: Adjust settings or sampling areas in the removal tool workspace and check the preview.
original_steps: If the result is not satisfactory, use the Content-Aware Fill workspace: - Go to Edit > Content-Aware Fill. - Use the masking tool to exclude unwanted areas from the sample. - Adjust the selection area using the Lasso Tool if needed. - Click OK to apply the changes and deselect with Ctrl + D.
Adjust Clone tool settings such as diameter, hardness, and healing as needed.
In the Content-Aware Fill workspace, you will see the selected area and a preview of the fill result.
On the left side, the green overlay shows the areas Photoshop will sample from to fill the selection.
Use the Eraser Tool to remove areas from the green overlay that you don't want Photoshop to sample from.
Ensure that only the areas you want to use for sampling are highlighted in green.
Check the preview on the right to see the result of the content-aware fill.

title: Nondestructive Editing
description: Create a new layer and enable 'Sample All Layers' for nondestructive editing.
original_steps: For nondestructive editing, create a new layer and enable 'Sample All Layers' in the Remove Tool options.

title: Touch Up
description: Use additional tools to touch up and blend the area seamlessly.
original_steps: Use the Clone Stamp Tool for fine-tuning: - Create a new layer and set the Clone Stamp Tool to 'Current and Below'. - Alt-click (Option-click on Mac) to sample an area and paint over artifacts.

For removing straight lines like power lines, use the Spot Healing Brush Tool: - Create a new layer and enable 'Sample All Layers'. - Click at the start of the line, hold Shift, and click at the end to remove it.

For removing braces or small details, use the Brush Tool: - Create a new layer and sample the color of the area to paint over. - Use a soft brush with low hardness and adjust opacity for blending. - Paint over the area, sampling colors as needed to blend smoothly.
Clone in small sections to maintain control and smoothness.
Use the Polygonal Lasso tool to select any remaining areas to fix.
Feather the selection and use the Clone Stamp tool to paint over these areas.
Select the Spot Healing Brush Tool from the toolbar.
Paint over the object you want to remove and observe the result.
To use the new Remove Tool, ensure you have the Photoshop Beta version installed from the Creative Cloud Beta Apps section.
Select the Remove Tool from the Healing group in the toolbar.
Paint over the object you want to remove and observe the result.
Use 'Remove After Each Stroke' for immediate fixes or leave it unchecked to apply changes after multiple strokes.
If needed, paint over any remaining artifacts to fix them.
Touch up the removal using the Clone Stamp Tool: Set flow to less than 5 and low opacity, hold Alt and click to set a reference point, and paint to blend the area seamlessly.
For smaller areas, use the Remove tool by creating a new layer and enabling 'Sample All Layers'.
Paint over the areas you want to remove with the Remove tool and press Enter to apply changes.
Use the Remove tool to touch up any remaining areas outside the selection.

title: Protect Areas
description: Use selections to protect certain parts of the image before using removal tools.
original_steps: For complex areas, use selections to protect certain parts of the image before using the Remove Tool.

title: Maintain Perspective
description: Use perspective tools to maintain perspective while cloning.
original_steps: Define the perspective by creating a new layer and going to Filter > Vanishing Point.
Use the Create Plane tool to mark the four corners of the area with perspective.
Use the Clone tool within the Vanishing Point dialog to clone areas while maintaining perspective.

title: Review and Adjust
description: Review the result and make final adjustments to ensure the image looks seamless.
original_steps: Deselect the selection by pressing Ctrl (or Command) D.
Deselect the selection and review the image for any remaining defects.
If the result is unsatisfactory, save it as a snapshot in the History panel.
Deselect the selection using Ctrl or Command + D and save the result as a history state.
Compare results using the History panel to see the effectiveness of different tools.
Once satisfied with the result, choose to output the fill to a new layer.
Click 'OK' to apply the changes and remove the object from the image.
For complex backgrounds, manually adjust the Content-Aware Fill settings by going to Edit > Content-Aware Fill and selecting the data to use for filling.
Review the variations provided and select the one that looks best.
To fix any issues with the generative fill, use the Object Selection tool to select the area you want to restore.
With the selection active, mask out the problem areas on the generative fill layer using a brush with the foreground color set to black.
Invert the selection to mask out additional problem areas if needed.
For final adjustments, use the Lasso tool to create a smaller selection and apply Generative Fill again.
Review the final image to ensure all unwanted objects are removed and the image looks seamless.

title: Repeat Process
description: Repeat the process for any other objects you want to remove.
original_steps: Repeat the process for any other large objects you want to remove.

title: Save Work
description: Save your work after completing the editing process.
original_steps: Make final adjustments and save your work.
